message.content:
Research how to create a minimal UXP plugin that loads in Adobe Premiere Pro.

I need to find:
1. The exact manifest.json format that works with Premiere Pro UXP
2. The correct host app ID and minimum version
3. A minimal working example

Search for:
- Adobe Premiere Pro UXP plugin manifest.json example
- Premiere Pro UXP getting started
- UXP Premiere Pro sample plugin GitHub
- adobe/uxp-premiere-pro-samples
- Premiere Pro UXP manifest version
- "PremierePro" UXP manifest

Look at:
- Official Adobe UXP documentation for Premiere Pro
- GitHub repos with working Premiere Pro UXP plugins
- Adobe developer forums for Premiere Pro UXP issues

I need the EXACT manifest.json that works - the current one loads in UXP Developer Tool but doesn't load in Premiere Pro when clicking "Load".

Return:
1. A working manifest.json example
2. The minimal index.html needed
3. Any other required files
4. Step-by-step loading instructions

input.query: Adobe Premiere Pro UXP plugin manifest.json example 2024 2025

Based on the search results, here's the information about Premiere Pro UXP manifest.json host configuration:

## Premiere Pro UXP Host ID

For Premiere Pro UXP plugins, the manifest "host" entry should use `"app": "PremierePro"`.

### Key Manifest Details:

Premiere supports manifest version "5".(no content)Each UXP plugin must have one manifest.json file that the host application uses to load and manage the plugin. In addition to core metadata such as the plugin's name, version, icons, and entry points, the manifest specifies permissions, compatibility details, and other definitions that shape how the plugin integrates with the host environment.

### Host Definition Structure:

UXP plugin .ccx installers can target only one host application at a time; in fact, the host property in the manifest.json file must be a single object of type HostDefinition. Only during development, for convenience, you can assign to the host property an array of HostDefinition objects, allowing the plugin to be loaded in multiple applications simultaneously.(no content)The minimum version of the host app that the plugin supports is specified in the x.y.z format. The maximum version also uses the x.y.z format, with the default value being the latest version of the host app.

### Important Note:

Currently, only Premiere Pro Beta builds support UXP plugins.

### Example Host Configuration:

```json
{
  "manifestVersion": 5,
  "host": {
    "app": "PremierePro",
    "minVersion": "25.0.0"
  }
}
```


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "adobe/uxp-premiere-pro-samples GitHub"

Links: [{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples"},{"title":"Premiere Pro panels - Adobe-CEP/Samples","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/ReadMe.md"},{"title":"uxp-premiere-pro-samples/README.md at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples/blob/main/README.md"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro"},{"title":"Starters and samples","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/starters-samples/"},{"title":"Solved: Full UXP support ETA - Adobe Product Community - 15352929","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/full-uxp-support-eta/td-p/15352929"},{"title":"Samples/PProPanel at master · Adobe-CEP/Samples","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel"},{"title":"The Premiere UXP API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/"},{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"Solved: UXP: Everything I need to know? - Adobe Product Community - 15476462","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/uxp-everything-i-need-to-know/m-p/15476462"}]

Here are the search results for "adobe/uxp-premiere-pro-samples GitHub":

## AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples

The official Adobe UXP Premiere Pro samples repository contains Adobe third-party sample panels, including a premiere-api directory. To build, you open your console/terminal/command prompt into sample-panels/premiere-api/html, and the plugin is built in the /build-html directory.

**Repository:** https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples

### Key Information

As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which Adobe will remove support for CEP extensibility.

### Related Resources

- The official Adobe developer documentation provides sample plugins and starter templates to accelerate UXP plugin development. When building UXP plugins for Premiere, you don't need to start from scratch. Adobe provides two types of resources: Samples (complete, working examples) and Starters (minimal templates with framework setup).

- **Documentation:** https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **Developer Forum:** https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105

### Getting Started

The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) provides a quick way to scaffold your plugin project from a set of starter templates. Open the UDT and click Create Plugin, set the project details, select a folder, and the UXP Developer Tool will create a new folder named after the Plugin ID.(no content)Adobe notes that their UXP sample plugins still require some thinking. Downloading the samples and playing with them in UXP Developer Tools, and/or your favorite JavaScript debugger, remains the recommended approach.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP plugin manifest.json:

## Adobe Premiere Pro UXP Plugin Manifest.json Overview

UXP has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6.(no content)To build UXP plugins, you need Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.

### Manifest Basics

Each UXP plugin must have one manifest.json file that the host application uses to load and manage the plugin. In addition to core metadata such as the plugin's name, version, icons, and entry points, the manifest specifies permissions, compatibility details, and other definitions that shape how the plugin integrates with the host environment. Most importantly, it contains your plugin ID, which uniquely identifies your plugin when it's installed in the host application.(no content)Premiere supports manifest version "5".

### Key Manifest Properties

- The manifestVersion indicates the version of the manifest schema.
- The ID uniquely identifies a plugin and is used to disambiguate plugin contexts, storage, errors, etc. For plugins distributed through the plugin marketplace, the id has to match the one set in the Developer Distribution portal.
- The main property indicates the primary JavaScript or HTML file, relative to the plugin's installation directory. It supports HTML and JS files, such as index.html and index.js. If not specified, main.js is used.
- The entrypoints array defines the entrypoints that the plugin provides; currently, only Commands and Panels are supported.

### Permissions

To ensure that plugins are secure, UXP requires that plugins declare the permissions they need to function. Permissions not explicitly declared will be denied by default.(no content)Permission-based APIs need to be allow-listed in your plugin's manifest.json. For example, to use the file system or make network requests, you must declare the appropriate permissions.

### Icons

Icons are an array representing the overall plugin or panel icon. The host application uses these icons to present the plugin to the user. If the icons array is missing, a default icon will be used.(no content)The path to the icon is relative to the plugin's installation directory and supports PNG (.png), JPG (.jpg or .jpeg), and SVG (.svg) files.

### Development Notes

Only during development, for convenience, you can assign to the host property an array of HostDefinition objects, allowing the plugin to be loaded in multiple applications simultaneously.(no content)If you make any changes to the manifest.json file, you must manually unload and reload the plugin. In the UXP Developer Tool, in the row for your plugin, click Unload and then Load & Watch once more.

### Resources

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- Adobe has updated sample code to help developers hit the ground running. The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP.
- Sample plugins are available on GitHub at: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

toolUseResult: Error: Request failed with status code 404

content.content:
# Manifest.json Configuration for Premiere Pro UXP Plugins

Based on the repository content provided, I cannot locate the specific manifest.json files or their exact configurations in the displayed web page excerpt. The README references that developers should navigate to `premiere-api/build-html/manifest.json` when loading plugins into the UXP Developer Tool, but the actual manifest structure and contents aren't included in this view.

To find the manifest configuration details, you would need to:

1. **Clone the repository** and navigate to `sample-panels/premiere-api/build-html/` directory
2. **Examine the source files** in `sample-panels/premiere-api/html/` before the build process
3. **Review the project structure** to understand host requirements, manifest versions, and entry point definitions

The README confirms this is an Apache-2.0 licensed repository with working sample code, but the actual manifest specifications aren't visible in the current page content. You'll need direct file access to see the precise host configurations and entry points for functional Premiere Pro UXP plugins.

input.prompt: Get the manifest.json example and host app ID

input.query: Premiere Pro UXP manifest.json "PPRO" OR "PremierePro" host app example working

content.content:
# PremierePro UXP Plugin Manifest

The manifest.json file contains the complete configuration for a Premier Pro plugin. Here are the key details:

**Core Information:**
- **ID:** com.adobe.ppro.samples
- **Version:** 1.0.0
- **Manifest Version:** 5
- **Host:** Premier Pro (minimum version 25.1.0)

**Permissions:**
The plugin requests access to the local file system and clipboard functionality for reading and writing.

**Panel Configuration:**
The single entrypoint defines a dockable panel with:
- Size constraints: minimum 430×500px, maximum 2000×2000px
- Preferred docked dimensions: 230×300px
- Preferred floating dimensions: 400×300px
- Dual-theme icon set (dark and light variants at 23×23px)

**Visual Assets:**
A 48×48px plugin icon supports all themes and appears in the plugin list.

The structure follows Adobe's UXP plugin standards for integrating custom panels into the Premier Pro interface.

toolUseResult.result:
# PremierePro UXP Plugin Manifest

The manifest.json file contains the complete configuration for a Premier Pro plugin. Here are the key details:

**Core Information:**
- **ID:** com.adobe.ppro.samples
- **Version:** 1.0.0
- **Manifest Version:** 5
- **Host:** Premier Pro (minimum version 25.1.0)

**Permissions:**
The plugin requests access to the local file system and clipboard functionality for reading and writing.

**Panel Configuration:**
The single entrypoint defines a dockable panel with:
- Size constraints: minimum 430×500px, maximum 2000×2000px
- Preferred docked dimensions: 230×300px
- Preferred floating dimensions: 400×300px
- Dual-theme icon set (dark and light variants at 23×23px)

**Visual Assets:**
A 48×48px plugin icon supports all themes and appears in the plugin list.

The structure follows Adobe's UXP plugin standards for integrating custom panels into the Premier Pro interface.

Based on the search results, here's information about Premiere Pro UXP manifest.json host app configuration:

## Premiere Pro UXP Manifest Configuration

Each UXP plugin must have one manifest.json file that the host application uses to load and manage the plugin.(no content)The manifest indicates the version of the schema, and Premiere supports version "5".

### Host App Identifier

Based on the search results, there's an important issue with the host app identifier:

When developing a UXP plugin for Premiere Pro, users report getting the error "Plugin Load Failed. Host Application specified is not available. Make sure the host application is started." when the manifest "host" entry is set to "app": "PremierePro".(no content)Currently, only Premiere Pro Beta builds support UXP plugins.

### Getting Started

Before starting, make sure you have Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later installed.(no content)Premiere's Developer Mode should be enabled. Open the Settings menu, select the Plugins tab and select the Enable developer mode checkbox. You will need to restart Premiere for the changes to take effect.

### Sample Plugins

To load a plugin: Click Add Plugin, navigate to the premiere-api/build-html/manifest.json, and click Open. The UXP sample plugin displays in Premiere Pro Beta.

Adobe provides official sample plugins at the GitHub repository: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples

### Key Manifest Components

In addition to core metadata such as the plugin's name, version, icons, and entry points, the manifest specifies permissions, compatibility details, and other definitions that shape how the plugin integrates with the host environment.(no content)To ensure that plugins are secure, UXP requires that plugins declare the permissions they need to function. Permissions not explicitly declared will be denied by default.

For the specific host app value for Premiere Pro in UXP manifests, the documentation and community posts indicate that `"PremierePro"` is used in the host entry, though this currently only works with Premiere Pro Beta builds.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

input.prompt: Show me the complete raw JSON content
What is the solution to the "Host Application specified is not available" error? What is the correct host app ID and version for Premiere Pro UXP plugins?

content.content:
# UXP Plugin Premiere Pro Error Solution

Based on the Adobe Community discussion, the issue stems from a **platform limitation rather than a configuration problem**.

## The Problem

The user encountered: "Plugin Load Failed. Host Application specified is not available."

## The Solution

According to Adobe Employee Bruce Bullis's response: **"Currently, only Premiere Pro _Beta_ builds support UXP plugins."**

## What This Means

- UXP plugins are **not supported** in standard Premiere Pro releases
- You must use a **beta version** of Premiere Pro for UXP plugin development
- The user's manifest configuration and permissions were likely correct; the standard version simply lacks UXP support
- This explains why the same plugin worked fine with Photoshop and InDesign—those applications have broader UXP support in their current versions

## Recommendation

Install a Premiere Pro beta build from Adobe's beta program to enable UXP plugin development and testing.

toolUseResult.result:
# UXP Plugin Premiere Pro Error Solution

Based on the Adobe Community discussion, the issue stems from a **platform limitation rather than a configuration problem**.

## The Problem

The user encountered: "Plugin Load Failed. Host Application specified is not available."

## The Solution

According to Adobe Employee Bruce Bullis's response: **"Currently, only Premiere Pro _Beta_ builds support UXP plugins."**

## What This Means

- UXP plugins are **not supported** in standard Premiere Pro releases
- You must use a **beta version** of Premiere Pro for UXP plugin development
- The user's manifest configuration and permissions were likely correct; the standard version simply lacks UXP support
- This explains why the same plugin worked fine with Photoshop and InDesign—those applications have broader UXP support in their current versions

## Recommendation

Install a Premiere Pro beta build from Adobe's beta program to enable UXP plugin development and testing.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro 25.6 UXP plugin support:

## Premiere Pro 25.6 UXP Plugin Support

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6.(no content)This release represents a major step forward in modernizing Adobe's extensibility ecosystem.

### Key Details

- UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.
- UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.

### Requirements for Development

Before you start, make sure you have Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.(no content)UXP is a JavaScript-based extensibility platform (ES6/ECMAScript 2015 compliant) that represents a comprehensive solution letting you use Web technologies to build new features and tools for Desktop applications.

### Distribution and Access

- If your plugin is polished and ready for distribution, you can now submit it to the Adobe Marketplace for approval.
- Installed UXP plugins can be found in the new UXP Plugins submenu under 'Window'.

### CEP Extension Transition

CEP extensions are still supported. The plan is to continue to support them for a calendar year beyond the release of UXP extensibility (in non-beta PPro builds).

### Resources

- Adobe has updated their sample code to help developers get started. The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP.
- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

input.prompt: What is the solution to the UXP plugin not loading in Premiere Pro 25.6? Get any manifest.json fixes or configuration changes needed.

input.query: Premiere Pro UXP "Enable developer mode" settings plugins load

content.content:
# UXP Plugin Loading Solution for Premiere Pro 25.6

Based on the Adobe Community discussion, the issue is with the plugin directory location and naming convention.

## The Problem
Placing the plugin folder in `~/Library/Application Support/Adobe/UXP/Extensions/` doesn't work. The plugin won't appear in the UXP Extensions menu.

## The Solution
According to Bruce Bullis (Adobe Employee), the correct location is:

**`~/Library/Application Support/Adobe/UXP/Plugins/External`**

## Critical Naming Requirement
The containing folder must follow this exact format:
- **`{plugin-id}_{version-number}`**

For example, if your manifest.json contains:
- `id`: `com.adobe.ppro.samples`
- `version`: `1.0.0`

Then the folder must be named: **`com.adobe.ppro.samples_1.0.0`**

## Key Points
- The version number must be three digits (X.Y.Z format)
- No modifications to manifest.json are needed
- This applies specifically to Premiere Pro 25.6 Beta
- CEP (classic extensions) remain fully supported for at least one calendar year after UXP becomes available in non-beta builds

Once properly located and named, your plugin should appear in the UXP Extensions menu without requiring the UXP Developer Tool.

# UXP Plugin Loading Solution for Premiere Pro 25.6

Based on the Adobe Community discussion, the issue is with the plugin directory location and naming convention.

## The Problem
Placing the plugin folder in `~/Library/Application Support/Adobe/UXP/Extensions/` doesn't work. The plugin won't appear in the UXP Extensions menu.

## The Solution
According to Bruce Bullis (Adobe Employee), the correct location is:

**`~/Library/Application Support/Adobe/UXP/Plugins/External`**

## Critical Naming Requirement
The containing folder must follow this exact format:
- **`{plugin-id}_{version-number}`**

For example, if your manifest.json contains:
- `id`: `com.adobe.ppro.samples`
- `version`: `1.0.0`

Then the folder must be named: **`com.adobe.ppro.samples_1.0.0`**

## Key Points
- The version number must be three digits (X.Y.Z format)
- No modifications to manifest.json are needed
- This applies specifically to Premiere Pro 25.6 Beta
- CEP (classic extensions) remain fully supported for at least one calendar year after UXP becomes available in non-beta builds

Once properly located and named, your plugin should appear in the UXP Extensions menu without requiring the UXP Developer Tool.

Links: [{"title":"Essential Development Tools for UXP","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/introduction/essentials/dev-tools/"},{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"UXP developer tools","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/indesign/uxp/introduction/essentials/dev-tools/"},{"title":"Releases · AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop/releases"},{"title":"\"plugin load failed\" for newly created and added plugins - UXP Developer Tool - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/plugin-load-failed-for-newly-created-and-added-plugins/6209"},{"title":"Installation","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/devtool/installation/"},{"title":"Enable Developer Mode error displays, despite developer mode being enabled in Photoshop - UXP Developer Tool - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/enable-developer-mode-error-displays-despite-developer-mode-being-enabled-in-photoshop/5340"}]

Based on my search results, here's the information about enabling developer mode for Premiere Pro UXP plugins:

## Enabling Developer Mode in Premiere Pro for UXP Plugins

Premiere's Developer Mode should be enabled. Open the Settings menu, select the Plugins tab and select the "Enable developer mode" checkbox. You will need to restart Premiere for the changes to take effect.

### UXP Developer Tool Requirements

The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications. UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.(no content)When you launch the Developer Tool for the first time, you'll be prompted to enable Developer Mode. This is required for you to load plugins in development into the application. Once you click Enable, elevated permissions will be requested, and you may be required to enter your password or approve an action from the Developer Tool.

### Manual Configuration (if automatic enabling fails)

If you have problems with this step, you can also configure Developer Mode manually, although you must have Administrative privileges to do so. Navigate to `/Library/Application Support/Adobe/UXP/Developer` on macOS, or `%CommonProgramFiles%/Adobe/UXP/Developer` on Windows. If the folder does not exist, you can create it—you'll need administrative rights. Create a new file named `settings.json` with the appropriate content—you'll need administrative rights to save the file.

### Loading and Reloading Plugins

If you make any changes to the manifest.json file, you must manually unload and reload the plugin. In the UXP Developer Tool, in the row for your plugin, click Unload and then Load & Watch once more.(no content)Admin privileges are required to use UDT. The UXP Developer Tool requires administrator-level privileges to run correctly.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Get started - UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/getting-started/"},{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples"},{"title":"Starters and samples","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/starters-samples/"},{"title":"Premiere and UXP","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/introduction/"},{"title":"The Premiere UXP API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/"},{"title":"Solved: UXP: Everything I need to know? - Adobe Product Community - 15476462","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/uxp-everything-i-need-to-know/m-p/15476462"},{"title":"uxp-premiere-pro-samples/README.md at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples/blob/main/README.md"},{"title":"HTML Events and Listeners","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/recipes/html-events/"},{"title":"Premiere API—UXP for Adobe Premiere","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about creating a minimal Premiere Pro UXP plugin with an index.html hello world example:

## Getting Started with Premiere Pro UXP Plugins

### Prerequisites
Before you start, make sure you have the following software installed: Premiere (v25.6) or later, UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later, and a code editor of your choice—for example, Visual Studio Code or Cursor.(no content)Premiere's Developer Mode should be enabled. Open the Settings menu, select the Plugins tab and select the Enable developer mode checkbox. You will need to restart Premiere for the changes to take effect.

### Creating a Plugin

The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) provides a quick way to scaffold your plugin project from a set of starter templates. Open the UDT and click Create Plugin. A dialog appears, allowing you to set the project details, then click Select Folder and choose a location on your computer where you want to scaffold the plugin.(no content)The UXP Developer Tool will create a new folder with the name you specified in the location you specified. The folder will contain the files needed for your plugin.

### The index.html File

Open the index.html file in your code editor. This file contains the HTML code that defines the visual content of your plugin's panel.(no content)You can change it to whatever you want. For example, you could change the heading to say "My First Plugin".

### Loading and Reloading

Thanks to the Watch & Reload feature, the changes will be automatically reflected in the host application.(no content)If you make any changes to the manifest.json file, you must manually unload and reload the plugin. In the UXP Developer Tool, in the row for your plugin, click Unload and then Load & Watch once more.

### Sample Resources

When building UXP plugins for Premiere, you don't need to start from scratch. Adobe provides two types of resources: Samples (complete, working examples that demonstrate specific features or use cases) and Starters (minimal templates with framework setup to help you begin a new plugin project).(no content)The UXP Developer Tool is available for download through Creative Cloud Desktop. You can find Adobe's third-party sample panel in the premiere-api directory from the GitHub repository.

### Official Resources
- **Getting Started Guide**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/getting-started/
- **Building Your First Plugin**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/
- **Sample Plugins Repository**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

toolUseResult.query: Premiere Pro UXP minimal index.html hello world example

content.title: Solved: UXP: Everything I need to know? - Adobe Product Community - 15476462

input.prompt: Show me the complete HTML content

content.content:
# Complete HTML Content

The webpage is an Adobe Premiere Pro plugin interface with a comprehensive console and control panel. Here's what it contains:

## Structure

The document includes:
- A fixed header with "Console" displaying status as "Ready"
- Active project and sequence name indicators
- A large footer section with organized button controls

## Main Sections

The interface organizes functionality into these categories:

1. **Project** - Open, save, and manage projects
2. **Sequence** - Create and edit sequences, manage tracks
3. **Markers** - Add and manipulate various marker types
4. **Project Panel** - Manage bins, items, and media properties
5. **Metadata** - Access and modify project metadata
6. **Source Monitor** - Control playback and file opening
7. **Keyframe** - Set and manage animation keyframes
8. **Effects & Transitions** - Apply and remove effects
9. **Properties** - Manage sequence and item properties
10. **Settings** - Configure project and application settings
11. **Export/Import** - Handle file export and composition importing
12. **Encoder** - Queue items to Adobe Media Encoder
13. **Transcripts** - Import/export transcript data

## Styling

The interface uses a dark theme (#222 background) with white text, featuring fixed header positioning, hover-activated clear button, and scrollable content areas.

1. **Project** - Open, save, and manage projects
2. **Sequence** - Create and edit sequences, manage tracks

## Styling

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about the UXP manifest host app configuration for Premiere Pro.

## UXP Manifest Host App for Premiere Pro

For Premiere Pro UXP plugins, the host app value should be `"premierepro"` (lowercase). Here's an example from the manifest host object:

```json
host: [
  {
    app: "premierepro",
    minVersion: "22.3",
    data: {
      apiVersion: 2,
      loadEvent: "startup",
      enableMenuRecording: true,
    },
  },
],
```


### Key Points

1. The entry point to Premiere APIs is the app object, which you `require()` from the "premierepro" module.

2. A common issue developers encounter is using `"PremierePro"` (with capital letters) instead of the correct lowercase `"premierepro"`. Using the incorrect case results in "Host Application specified is not available" errors.

3. Only during development, for convenience, you can assign to the host property an array of HostDefinition objects, allowing the plugin to be loaded in multiple applications simultaneously.

4. UXP plugin .ccx installers can target only one host application at a time; in fact, the host property in the manifest.json file must be a single object of type HostDefinition.

5. Currently, only Premiere Pro Beta builds support UXP plugins.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## UXP Manifest Host App for Premiere Pro

For Premiere Pro UXP plugins, the host app value should be `"premierepro"` (lowercase). Here's an example from the manifest host object:

```json

    minVersion: "22.3",

      apiVersion: 2,
      loadEvent: "startup",
      enableMenuRecording: true,

```


### Key Points

1. The entry point to Premiere APIs is the app object, which you `require()` from the "premierepro" module.

2. A common issue developers encounter is using `"PremierePro"` (with capital letters) instead of the correct lowercase `"premierepro"`. Using the incorrect case results in "Host Application specified is not available" errors.

3. Only during development, for convenience, you can assign to the host property an array of HostDefinition objects, allowing the plugin to be loaded in multiple applications simultaneously.

4. UXP plugin .ccx installers can target only one host application at a time; in fact, the host property in the manifest.json file must be a single object of type HostDefinition.

5. Currently, only Premiere Pro Beta builds support UXP plugins.
